title: 'Sesame Street' Turns 45
teaser: NPR's Eric Deggans talks about how the children's TV show featuring Jim Henson's muppets has managed to stay relevant for 45 years.
contentencoded:
Today in 1969, the first episode of Sesame Street aired on public television. A little girl named Sally is new to the neighborhood, and she meets some of the residents, including an awkward, nervous Big Bird.

Forty-five years later, Sesame Street is going strong, with nearly a million viewers every episode, according to PBS.

These days, Alistair Cookie no longer smokes a pipe on Monsterpiece Theatre, and the theme song has a jazzier beat than it used to.

NPR’s TV Critic Eric Deggans tells Here & Now’s Sacha Pfeiffer about how Sesame Street has managed to stay relevant for almost half a century.

Guest

  • Eric Deggans, TV critic for NPR. He tweets @Deggans.
